awd_titl_txt: Surface Temperature Generated in Oscillating Contact
awd_abstract_narration: Fretting fatigue and fretting corrosion are common types of                     tribological damage caused by oscillating contacts. The level of                surface temperature generated by friction in the contact zone under             these conditions and its effect on the fretting process will be                 studied. Experimental temperature measurements obtained by infrared             microscopy will be combined with tribological fretting data and with            relevant heat transfer analyses to formulate a model for the role of            temperature in fretting damage. Effects of sliding distance and                 velocity as well as of oxide films will be included. The study will             result in a better understanding of the fretting process and could              lead to better guidelines for materials selection and development for           fretting conditions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
